Award.AwardTitle: As Our Grandparents Told It: Strengthening Gwichin and Koyukon Athabascan Languages Through Storytelling
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a proposal to fund the travel of two Alaska Native researcers, MA student Allan Hayton and Tribal scholar Dewey Hoffman, to present their research on Gwichin and Koyukon Athabaskan language and culture at the international World Indigenous Peoples Conference on Education in Cusco, Peru, August 2011.

POR.DRECONTENT:
World Indigenous People’s Conference on Education

Cusco, Peru August 14-18, 2011

Introduction

The 9th World Indigenous People’s Conference on Education was held August 14-18 2011 in Cusco, Peru. Two attendees from Alaska, Allan Hayton and Dewey Hoffman, were able to attend through the generous support of the National Science Foundation, and the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Allan Hayton is an MA candidate in applied linguistics at UAF. Dewey Hoffman is a Native American Studies graduate of Dartmouth College. Their presentation abstract was submitted to WIPCE April 30, 2011.

Allan Hayton is Gwich’in Athabascan from Arctic Village, Alaska.  Allan is committed to teaching his Gwich’in language, and sharing his experiences and lessons learned with other Indigenous language teachers. Allan seeks to use his background in theatre as a way to engage young language learners.

Dewey Kk’o?eyo Hoffman was born into the Koyukon Athabascan communities in Ruby and Galena, Alaska and the Swiss-American community in Bozeman, Montana to Dee Olin and David Hoffman. A novice student of Denaakkenaage’, he hopes to progress in his language, and actively contribute to ongoing efforts to create new speakers. Dewey shares some of the barriers and challenges as a learner of Koyukon language.

Project Abstract

AS OUR GRANDPARENTS TOLD IT: STRENGTHENING GWICH’IN AND KOYUKON ATHABASCAN LANGUAGES THROUGH STORYTELLING

This round table discussion will build on the understanding that storytelling is a central part of Gwich’in & Koyukon Athabascan cultures in Alaska, and is the primary way human beings everywhere order the world around them and create meaning. Storytelling can be a tool in revitalizing our endangered languages, and in shaping our individual identities as Indigenous peoples. Using storytelling as a starting point of engagement, the presenters will involve participants in a discussion of how we can use language learning for the purpose of strengthening ourselves and our communities.

We may consider the following questions: “How can storytelling enhance language learning and teaching?”; “How do perceptions of Indigenous languages contribute to their revitalization or continued loss?”; or “Where do our individual stories fit into the global context of indigenous language strengthening?” Sharing how other real people are addressing such questions can deepen our collective understanding and provide inspiration for finding solutions.

Language and identity are closely linked, and this relationship is core to the struggle of our continued survival as Indigenous peoples. The simple question “Do you speak your Native language?” evokes in each individual a kaleidoscope of emotions and responses, from intense pride to a deep-seeded sense of loss. How do different indigenous people think about learning their indigenous languages, and how can we work to craft indigenous language learning strategies that are adaptable enough to consider dynamic life experiences?
